title: Bug 7734: System can be shut down without savefile warnings
OB: When a WSWB session is open with some opened, dirty .txt file, shutting down Windows will cause the loss of the changes in the .txt file.
EB: The system should provide a dialog box with the message 'Do you want to save your file?' and options 'Yes', 'No', and 'Cancel' (which halts the shutdown).
SR:
To reproduce the issue:
1. Start WSWB and create a new project.
2. Create a text file in the project and add a line of text to it. Notice that the text file is marked as dirty.
3. Left click on the Windows Start menu and select the 'Shut Down' command to shutdown/reboot the computer.

Expected results:
A warning or question message box should appear, giving users a chance to save their dirty file(s) before the computer is shut down/rebooted.

Actual results:
There is no warning or question message box, and the computer is shut down/rebooted immediately without a chance to save the dirty file(s).

Note: Other Windows programs (like Word, Outlook, etc.) provide similar warnings before shutting down.
